paper.title: Easy to be hard: difficult problems for greedy algorithms

author.org: Artificial Intelligence Center SRI International 333 Ravenswood Ave. Menlo Park, CA 94025 konolige at ai.sri.com

paper.venue: Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning
paper.abstract: Abstract Recent advances in hill-climbing satisfiability methods have solved hard classes of problems, which are difficult for existing systematic methods such as Davis-Putnam. In this paper we examine a class of problems derived from crossword puzzles that is difficult for the hill-climbing methods, yet is easily solved by standard forward-checking algorithms. The characteristic feature of this class is its hierarchical nature: clusters of dependent variables, with a small number of connections between the clusters. Although the results are experimental and not theoretical, we speculate that any hierarchical constraint-satisfaction problem with certain characteristics will be difficult for naive greedy algorithms.
